brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides a rule for JetBrains Inspectopedia that checks for multiple id attributes in one entity. This is a common issue in JPA where an entity should only have one id attribute.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'entity-multiple-id-attributes' checks all classes in the project. If a class has the 'Entity' annotation, it then checks all fields in that class. If a field has the 'Id' annotation, it increments a counter. Finally, it asserts that the counter is less than or equal to 1, meaning there is at most one id attribute in the entity. If the assertion fails, it outputs a message indicating the fully qualified name of the entity class that has more than one id attribute.
PRE_model_validation: The rule 'entity-multiple-id-attributes' is syntactically correct and uses only the built-in functions provided. It follows the structure of the example rules and uses the functions 'getClasses', 'hasAnnotation', 'getFields', and 'getFQN'.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. https://www.baeldung.com/jpa-entity-identity: This page from Baeldung explains how to properly set up entity identity in JPA, emphasizing that each entity should have a unique id. It also discusses the use of the @Id annotation, which is relevant to the rule.
2. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/918374/doctrine2-more-than-one-field-as-identifier: This StackOverflow thread discusses the issue of having more than one id field in an entity, which is directly related to the rule. The consensus is that it's generally a bad practice.
